body: Island's Somber Past Q. When my uncle, an architect, died, among his effects I found pictures labeled ''North Brother Island Project -- April 5, 1946.'' The pictures appear to be of nice Art Deco hospital buildings. What are they and what happened to them? A. North Brother Island, off Hunts Point in the Bronx, is probably best remembered as the
title: F.Y.I.

body: The views are not commanding, unless you count the one of the exhaust stations for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. Yet champions of the Brooklyn Motor Inn say it is a promising idea for a new hotel in New York for an unlikely reason: it's in Red Hook. ''We've got everything you need right here,'' said Sal Faraone, manager of the Motor Inn, speaking
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; In Area Where Capone Roamed, Inn Burnishes a Changing Image

body: THE holiday season is generally the time to reconnect with family and friends, but at a party on Dec. 20 at a loft in Bushwick, Brooklyn, few of the guests had met previously -- at least not in person. They knew each other as subscribers to Suicidegirls.com, a Web site founded in 2001 that costs members $4 a year and features photographs of about
title: GOOD COMPANY; Connected by a Web Site, With Erotica Played Down

body: Like the ''easy to assemble'' train set wrapped in a bow under the Christmas tree, New Yorkers will get a gift early in the New Year that requires reading the instructions carefully. Verrrry carefully. And you still might not get it. The rehabilitation of the Manhattan Bridge is finally coming to an end after nearly two decades, which means that
title: Revised Subway Map (and Alphabet) Awaits Riders in '04

body: A woman was fatally hit by a truck in Bay Ridge yesterday, the police said. The woman, Janny Mak, 67, was pronounced dead at Lutheran Medical Center. The truck driver, John Gilly, 29, who was turning left onto 79th Street from Fourth Avenue, told the police that his truck would not stop. He was issued summonses for failing to yield to a pedestrian
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed By Truck

body: FABIO GRANATO and VITTORIO ASSAF have opened GEISHA , 33 East 61st Street, next door to one of the Serafina restaurants they own. The two-story space, designed by David Rockwell, has references to Japan and to geishas, like translucent umbrella-style lights over the bar. The chef, MICHAEL VERNON , a former sous-chef at Le Bernardin, and ERIC RIPERT
title: FOOD STUFF; Off the Menu

body: THE promise of beds in Brooklyn has the women waiting by the door. They know too well that sleeping several nights in a chair can swell the feet needed to keep moving, keep moving. So a bed is nice. The bus to Brooklyn is late, though, leaving the women to linger a bit longer at the Antonio G. Olivieri drop-in center, which operates out of an old
title: About New York; Promise of Cots Keeps Homeless On the Move

body: Men in buoyant insulated jumpsuits laid barriers over the boulders and sand along the Coney Island peninsula yesterday as federal investigators sought to assign responsibility for an oil spill in New York Bay. The shoreline, steps away from houses in Sea Gate, Brooklyn, was dotted with eyeball-size marbles of tar. Workers sought to keep more oil
title: Amid Muck, Officials Seek Answers in Oil Spill at Coney Island Peninsula

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took a shot yesterday at a potential political rival, Speaker Gifford Miller of the City Council, saying an e-mail message sent out by Mr. Miller's aide last week indicated that the speaker may be inappropriately using Council resources to begin a campaign for mayor. Mr. Miller, a Democrat, has been coy about any mayoral
title: Bloomberg Smells Rat in Message About Speaker

body: AS the New York City housing market flourished in much of the period between 1999 and 2002, the pace of apartment deregulation quickened in the most desirable neighborhoods of Manhattan and market rents rose sharply in much of the city, especially in Brooklyn and Queens, where median rents exceed $1,000 for the first time in some neighborhoods.
title: As Rents Rise, So Does Deregulation

body: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''German Echoes'' (F.Y.I., Nov. 9), about 190 Third Avenue. Your readers might also enjoy knowing that the building and its life as a beer hall is captured in O. Henry's short story ''The Halberdier of the Little Rheinschloss.'' This was one of two watering holes in the Gramercy Park area that O. Henry wrote about, the
title: Lingering Echoes Of an Old Beer Hall

My mission that day was to replace eight costumes for
title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/FOOD; Meals From Cabbies, Firemen and Everyone Else

body: EVERYONE knows the traditional New York classics, like E. B. White's ''Here Is New York,'' from 1949, and Joseph Mitchell's ''Bottom of the Harbor'' (1959). But what books published in the past quarter century might join their ranks? When the City section asked readers to nominate ''the new New York classics,'' more than 100 books were suggested.
title: NEW YORK VOICES; Winners' Tales: New York's New Classics

body: EVERY year I am offered a seat in a pace car of the New York City Marathon. To paraphrase Mel Brooks, it's good to be the sports columnist. The 26-mile, 385-yard tour via cordoned roads invokes the same reaction every year: I pledge to get in better running shape, and I renew my love vows for my hometown. Mostly, I get hungry. My attention span
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES/SALIVATING; 26.2 Miles of Food

author: E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com
body: Tip O'Neill liked to tell the story about Solomon, who, already blessed with great power and intelligence, wisely asked the Lord to give him ''a heart that hears.'' That's a lesson that could be helpful to Michael Bloomberg, the four-billion-dollar man who's got a lot of power and is certainly intelligent, but who hasn't connected in any emotional
title: An Earful for Bloomberg

body: Today is Election Day. All the contests are local, so the results will affect everyday lives -- from trash removal and taxes to safe streets, good schools and clean government. For some of the most competitive races and the five questions on the New York City ballot, here are our recommendations, beginning with just this: Vote. Polls are open from
title: Choices for Election Day

body: BECAUSE she is so recognizable, with her thick wraparound shades, Marla Runyan could not suffer anonymously. All three times she slowed to a walk yesterday, the acutely verbal New York fans shouted encouragement -- exactly the kind of stick-to-it-girl sympathy that a world-class athlete does not want to hear. ''Every time I was walking, I felt so
title: Sports of The Times; Too Famous To Suffer Unnoticed

body: The push-rim wheelchair division of the New York City Marathon went just about as Krige Schabort had expected yesterday. Despite tendinitis in his right shoulder, Schabort said he could win here for the second consecutive year and might even set a course record. Schabort, a South African who now lives in Georgia, was right. He won the men's race in
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON: WHEELCHAIR; Glue and Cable Wire Aid Tenacious Winner

body: Peter Keane, the owner of V.I.P. Auto Body on Rust Road in West Maspeth, Queens, looked across the street at the cleared and desolate 40 acres of the old Phelps Dodge copper smelting plant and, beyond it, Newtown Creek. He had heard that the city might build a freight yard there as part of an ambitious plan to link a citywide network of railroad
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST MASPETH; A Tunnel to Reduce Truck Traffic Might Add Trucks

body: There are 51 seats in the City Council, and all are up for grabs next Tuesday. Among the few truly competitive races, here are our choices in Brooklyn and Staten Island. Brooklyn: District 35 (Fort Greene, Clinton Hill and parts of Crown Heights, Prospect Heights and Bedford Stuyvesant) -- The contest in this district is the epilogue to the killing
title: Endorsements for the City Council

body: On the steps of City Hall, on public affairs television programs and in the offices of civic organizations and political parties, the chatter these days dwells on a single topic: nonpartisan elections. The referendum to end party primaries and make party affiliation an afterthought in local races has so dominated conversations that it is referred
title: Facing Vote to Alter Primaries, Many New Yorkers Just Yawn

body: OVER a four-week period this summer, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs seized 12 vehicles from unlicensed contractors in Queens who had provided home improvement services without obtaining the necessary license. To get the vehicles back, the contractors each had to pay $1,000 in fines, resolve outstanding complaints filed by
title: YOUR HOME; Contracting For Home Renovations

body: TWENTY-EIGHT stories above Central Park South, Manhattan looks like a vast sweep of green fringed by jagged piles of skyscrapers. Inside the sunken living room, an appointed tray of teas and pastries waits. Agnes Varis offers coffee and a slice of baklava, explaining that the housekeeper is on vacation, and scurries excitedly to her favorite
title: IN PERSON; The Democrats' Fairy Godmother

body: WE are a city of heroes. The rest of the country may clamor for po' boys and hoagies, grinders, subs, wedges or torpedoes, but New York knows what really constitutes a gigantic sandwich, and what raises the hero above those pretenders; what makes it gastronomic royalty. Let there be no misunderstanding by those who have never ventured to New York,
title: Hey, Po' Boy, Meet Some Real Heroes

body: The indictment this week of the Brooklyn Democratic leader, Clarence Norman Jr., has left many Democratic officials in Brooklyn worried about the tarnished image of their party when, they say, they should be working on organizing for the presidential primary next year. Others worry that the indictment of Mr. Norman, coming on the heels of scandals
title: Democrats In Brooklyn Fear for Image

body: New Yorkers may not like it, but they are, by necessity, great sharers. They share tables in restaurants, benches in parks, inches on sidewalks and air in the subway. In a living arrangement most of the country would probably find far too Marxist -- the co-op -- they even share responsibility for apartment buildings. Now, some people in the city
title: Taking the Co-op Out for a Spin; New Car Rental Idea Depends on Courtesy of Strangers

body: For New Yorkers, Brighton Beach is a charming curiosity, a little bit of Russia in their own backyard. They go to shop for food, mill among the stout old-timers and hear the exotic language. Even the occasional financial swindle in the news is regarded, at least by those who are not prosecutors, as more cultural quirk than grave crime. But lately
title: To Young, a Russian Enclave Is Too Much the Old Country

author: A.O. Scott is a movie critic for The New York Times and a frequent contributor to the magazine.
body: A few years ago, if you rode the D train from Brooklyn to Manhattan, your peripheral vision might have been surprised by a stroboscopic flicker of color at the mouth of the tunnel leading out onto the span of the Manhattan Bridge. If you adjusted your angle of vision properly, you could make out, through pillars and support walls, the bright Krylon
title: On The Edge Of The Neo-70's

body: A group of City Council members announced a proposal yesterday to regulate cybercafes, saying the businesses were much like the video arcades of the 1980's in that they were magnets for violence and truancy. The lawmakers held a news conference yesterday to respond to instances of serious violence that began at cybercafes in southwest Brooklyn in
title: Lawmakers, Citing Violence, Seek to Regulate Cybercafes

body: This is what cutting class looks like these days for many high school students in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn: A long, narrow room with two small fluorescent lights where boys sit at desks for hours on end, staring straight ahead at computer screens, rarely speaking to one another and more rarely seeing a girl. Teenagers in this
title: Brooklyn Violence Spills Outside Cybercafes

body: The fire was in the bedroom of a Bronx apartment. Firefighters broke down the door and found a mattress ablaze. They put the fire out, a battalion chief recorded that it was not suspicious, and they left. The charred mattress could have been quickly forgotten, just another remnant of the city's many anonymous fires that claim neither life nor limb,
title: Marshals Worry as Cuts Leave More Fires Uninvestigated

body: FELICE--Dr. Anthony B. Age 80 of Middletown, NJ, formerly of New York City and Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on September 24, 2003. Beloved husband of Clare Felice (nee Polcha). Dear father of Anthony, George, Mary Petillo and Terryann Capichana. Grandfather of 13. Funeral Monday from the John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Road, Middletown, NJ.

body: The day after the fight, the pool hall was quiet. There was the occasional deliveryman or a couple of teenagers looking for a quiet thrill banging on the video game machines. Nicholas Brooks, 14, of Bay Ridge lay in critical but stable condition at Lutheran Medical Center, beaten and stabbed. Three teenagers who had been detained by the police,
title: A Corner Shadowed by Racial Tensions

body: A 14-year-old boy was hospitalized in critical condition late yesterday after he was attacked in Brooklyn during what the police described as a confrontation between two groups of young people. Three teenagers were arrested following the incident, the police said, and were charged with gang assault. Other charges are pending. They identified one of
title: Boy, 14, Is Stabbed As Teenagers Clash

body: Ex-Council Maverick Turns to Marketing It seemed like a municipal maverick's quixotic quest. In 1997, Sal F. Albanese, a member of the New York City Council little known outside his Brooklyn district, ran against far-better-known candidates in the Democratic mayoral primary -- all for the chance to try to unseat a popular Republican. Mr. Albanese
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: The Fire Department will close one of New York City's two remaining full-time fire marshals offices on Thursday. Fire union officials warned yesterday that with fewer marshals, more fires were going uninvestigated. The department will close the marshals office at Fort Totten, Queens, the second office to close this year, for a savings of $1.4
title: Fire Marshals Losing Office; Some Say Cuts Hurt Inquiries

body: In the blue-collar corner, from Bay Ridge, 69 years old, 6-foot-1 and weighing in at 185 pounds was Ralph Perfetto. And in the white-collar corner, from Park Slope, 46 years old, 5-foot-10 and weighing in at 220 pounds was Alan M. Fleishman. In the end, cooler heads prevailed, but not before the two men, district leaders representing the yin and
title: 2 Brooklyn Politicians Concede They Are Unlikely Pugilists

body: When the Brooklyn Democratic Party met yesterday to pick its candidates for the state Supreme Court, the scene resembled nothing so much as a squeaky-clean and very serious student council election. The judicial convention, long held in a grimy courthouse jury room and in virtual secrecy, took place in an auditorium. There were, in a break with
title: Judicial Politics as Usual in Brooklyn, and Nearly a Brawl

body: Brooklyn residents who want to sink the 3.5-mile elevated stretch of the Gowanus Expressway underground got a chill last month when they learned that the state's Department of Transportation had designated $344 million to shore up the existing structure. The money will go toward resurfacingthe road, which state officials said isnecessary for
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH BROOKLYN; The State Patches Up a Road That Residents Want to Ditch

body: Some parishioners at churches around the city have started attending services with pockets full of quarters. They are not for the collection tray, but for feeding one-hour parking meters, 19,500 of which were put into service on Sundays between late last year and early this year. Some churches and elected officials have criticized the change,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Churchgoers Want Meters to Honor the Sabbath, Too

body: Touring classrooms filled with stacks of glossy new library books and cartons of math texts, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday declared the ''start of a new era'' in the New York City public schools, one he said was ''built on a solid foundation of accountability.'' But even as Mr. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein expressed
title: Mayor Hails 'New Era' in Schools Amid Crowding Fears

body: When a neighbor's dogs began barking regularly five summers ago, residents of a sleepy block in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, had no idea that the barking would only be part of their collective headache. The rest of that headache would be provided courtesy of that only-in-New-York experience: the Kafkaesque bureaucratic nightmare. It turns out that noise
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; Are Those Dogs Really Barking If the City Does Not Listen?

body: Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday that the Fire Department would transfer 20 firefighters with the most sick leave absences to other assignments in an effort to stem what he called abuses of its medical leave policy. The measures may seem counterintuitive: the firefighters will be moved from busy firehouses to less busy ones,
title: The Biggest Users of Sick Leave Face Transfer in Fire Department

body: To the Editor: Re Steven M. O'Neill's letter with the headline ''Tolls on Bridges: A Win-Win Deal'' (Aug. 17): Mr. O'Neill's ''win-win'' situation adds another tax to all city residents. Except for the Bronx, we live on islands in this city, and depend on the river crossings for everything. More tolls will just add a tax to all of our goods --
title: Bridge Tolls Not a Winning Idea

title: Bloomberg Shows Up, And Surprise! Loosens Up

body: Over the long weekend, the tales grew in the telling. Miles heroically crossed on foot. Eons trapped in the subway. A night on the sidewalk. Flights of stairs like Everest. So when many New Yorkers finally saw their co-workers yesterday for the first time since the blackout, it was time to brag -- and complain. Anthony Leone, 45, an MCI engineer,
title: THE BLACKOUT: NEW YORKERS; War Stories at the Water Cooler

A little before 8 a.m., about a dozen people suddenly appeared. A dispatcher asked their destination but got no reaction. As
title: THE BLACKOUT; Anywhere Free

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared war yesterday on the city's rat population, saying that the rodents had invaded homes and threatened public health for too long before announcing an expansion of the city's efforts to exterminate them. ''Our administration has zero tolerance for rats,'' he said. ''And I've got one message today, 'City to rats:
title: The Word on the Street? For New York's Rats, It's 'Goodbye'

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; Web Site Flares With Anti-Arab Sentiment

Mr. Carney notes that he and his wife, Joan, were drawn to the convenience of the train to the ferry, the express bus
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/New Dorp; Convenience Near Staten Island's Shore

author: Abby Ellin writes a column about young people for the Money & Business section of The Times.
body: IGNORE the razor wire twisted outside the windows, and the school building at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility feels like most other academic institutions. title: Cons In Class

Kjeldsen of Babylon, NY and David C. Kjeldsen of West Islip, NY. His son Norman Peter Kjeldsen of

body: There are hundreds of free shows in Manhattan: buildings going up or coming down; policemen running with their hands on their holsters; taxicab races seen from the 35th floor; young women walking in SoHo on the first warm day of spring. My favorite, after the young women, takes place on the far West Side, next to a pier, more than a dozen times a
title: Watching a Queen Make an Exit

author: Steve Kurutz is a staff writer for Details magazine.
body: THE Belt Parkway, which stretches for 36 miles from Owls Head Park in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to Long Island, is a road as bold and monolithic as New York City itself. The highway, which was built by Robert Moses, is lined with concrete barriers and colossal traffic jams on weekends. Driving the Belt is like skirting along the very heart of urbanism.
title: In the Still of the Night

title: Paid Notice: Deaths PUGLISI, , REV. MSGR. GUY J., PH.D.

title: A City at the Melting Point

body: DEAR DIARY: From time to time, I accompany a blind poet friend, Dennis, on walks through our neighborhood in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Dennis enjoys the sounds and smells we encounter as we walk down Third Avenue. He is able to smell the fruit stands and flowers on display. He is even able to keep count of the street numbers as we walk and the
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: SHE is white, looks like a runway model and comes from Australia, not South Central Los Angeles. But other than that, Jessy Moss is a typical gangster rapper. title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Jessy Moss; Soft Looks, Hard Raps

title: Recalling Days Before Age Took the T-Bird Away; Antique Cars Stir Memories of Youth Among Residents of a Geriatric Center

body: A Midtown financial corporation was indicted yesterday on charges of illegally transmitting at least $3 billion from shell companies, private investors and foreign exchange houses to offshore accounts, cheating the city, state and federal governments out of tens of millions of dollars in taxes in what prosecutors called the largest scheme of the
title: Laundering Of Billions Is Alleged

body: Generally, adding bike lanes to city streets makes them safer for cyclists, drivers and pedestrians alike. But ever since a bike lane was installed along Shore Road in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, some residents have worried that it will cause, rather than prevent, collisions. The problem, they say, is that the bike lane has gobbled up five feet of Shore
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; With a New Bike Safety Lane, a Road Feels Anything but Safer

body: McGONAGLE--Henry J., 62, of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. title: Paid Notice: Deaths MCGONAGLE, , HENRY J.

body: The brothers Atanasov -- Dimitre, Vladimir and Alex -- grumble about their after-school lessons like typical American boys; in their case, boys who are being forced to take up to five hours a week of ballroom-style dance lessons. ''I'm there 24/7,'' said Dimitre, who will not even tell his friends at Dyker Heights Intermediate School that he spends
title: The Russians Are Coming, Stepping Lightly

body: Later this month, as the Williamsburg Bridge marks its 100th year, the fireworks will be celebratory. But on the other side of Brooklyn, another 100-year-old structure is sparking a less festive combustion. A three-story house at 435 80th Street in Bay Ridge has become the focus of a candlelight vigil and angry meetings. In April, residents learned
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; Trying to Save A Centenarian From Developer

body: PFIFFERLING -- Nancy. Of Brooklyn, age 56, passed away June 1, 2003 of lung cancer. Survived by beloved husband Joe, producer ''ABC News 20/20'', and brother Neil Lehane. Celebratory Mass June 14th, 2003, 9:30 am Fontbonne Hall Academy, Bay Ridge where she taught languages for over 30 years. Contributions in her memory to Joan's Legacy, 27 Union
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PFIFFERLING, , NANCY

body: Rents for market-rate apartments in and around New York City have continued to slip this year, according to rental brokers and landlords, but not as steeply as they had during their nose dive from a breath-catching peak two years ago. ''It's not good for landlords, but it's certainly good for people entering the rental market,'' said James W.
title: Residential Real Estate; Market-Rate Rents Continue Downturn

body: State legislators are considering two proposals that would weaken a new state smoking ban by allowing people to light up in bars and restaurants that build stand-alone smoking rooms, or are operated by their owners. The proposals, which were introduced in separate Assembly and Senate bills on Wednesday, come less than two months after the
title: 2 Bills Would Soften Smoking Ban Approved 2 Months Ago

body: An 18-year-old man was fatally shot Saturday as he rode on the Belt Parkway in the back seat of a friend's car, the police said. The man, Francesco Santillo, and three friends had left a pool hall in Bay Ridge, just after 2 a.m., when the driver stopped at a light. Another car -- believed to be a white Lincoln with two women in the front seat and a
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Fatally Shot

body: I WAS always a finicky eater. But give me dessert first and I'm a happy camper. Perhaps that's because my mother realized early on that the easiest way to infuse milk into my system was from the cow to the cone. Besides the tinkling of bells on the Good Humor truck, one of my earliest memories is skipping to the corner drugstore near my childhood
title: Celebrating The Months Of Sundaes

title: To Get a Job, Become a Boss: The Lure of Owning a Franchise

body: Ferry service between Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan, one of the small changes wrought by the upheaval of Sept. 11, is slated to end next Wednesday, much to the consternation of some commuters and elected officials. The free service, which shuttles riders from the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park to Pier 11 in Lower Manhattan, was started just
title: Free Brooklyn-Manhattan Ferry to End Soon

body: An Iraqi man accused of working secretly as an agent for Iraqi intelligence in New York City was actually trying to help the United States learn about Iraq's intelligence activities, his lawyer said yesterday. The defendant, Raed Rokan al-Anbuge, whose father is a former diplomat at the United Nations, met regularly with the F.B.I. over the past
title: A NATION AT WAR: ESPIONAGE; Iraqi Man Was Actually A U.S. Agent, Lawyer Says

body: It was opening weekend at Coney Island, and Gregory Bitetzakis was ready at his snack bar on Surf Avenue. There were sugary funnel cakes, bags of airy cotton candy, cold sodas, greasy fried clams and smoking-hot corn cobs. But many passers-by were disappointed with the one item missing from the menu. ''Got to go down to the boardwalk for ice
title: In Coney Island, Cyclones (And a Crystal-Clear Day)

body: American marines moved today into the edges of Tikrit, the ancestral home of Saddam Hussein, after intense bombardment by jets and helicopter gunships. Marine officers said the resistance was significant, and they said they planned to carry out another attack on Monday. ''We got the foothold in the city that we wanted,'' Lt. Col. Bob Sinclair said.
title: A NATION AT WAR: COMBAT; U.S. TROOPS POISED TO OUST LOYALISTS IN NORTHERN CITY

body: HENDERSON-John J., of Bay Ridge Brooklyn, NY, died Monday March 24, 2003 in Manchester, CT. He was the son of the late John and Maud (Johnston) Henderson and brother to Olive Wall Manning and Daisy Bevers. He was a graduate of the Stevens Institute of Technology and was a US Army Veteran serving during the Korean War. John dedicated his life to
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HENDERSON, JOHN J.

body: Vincent J. Gentile finally became a city councilman yesterday as he was officially sworn in at City Hall. His campaign ended in February during a special election in the 43rd Council District in Brooklyn, in which he faced Rosemarie O'Keefe. But Mr. Gentile was forced to wait while election officials counted absentee and other paper ballots under
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Councilman Sworn In Weeks After Election

body: THE phone lines to Baghdad were jammed last week. But not much ever got said over these wires, which have been more a tool of surveillance than of communication since Saddam Hussein's Baath Party took power in 1968. Conversations between Iraqis in New York and Iraqis in Baghdad have typically gone something like this: New York: ''How are you?''
title: Muffled Voices

body: By the moment the war started, the old- timers -- the ones who may have lain in the trenches in one of the world wars -- had long since gone. At the Michael A. Rawley Jr. American Legion Post near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, the bar had only a few patrons and was quiet -- save the news of the conflict being broadcast on two televisions. Bob King
title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: REACTION -- THE VETERANS; Legion Post Is Quiet

body: LUBOW-Rae. Passed away at 91 on March 6, 2003 in Bronxville, N.Y. Born Rachel Bloom in New York. Widow of Samuel K. Maccabee and of Jay Lubow. A resident of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, for 53 years, lately of Hastings-onHudson, N.Y. Loving mother of Paul and George Maccabee. Grandmother of Jonathan, Laura and Claire. Laid to rest at Wellwood Cemetery,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LUBOW, RAE

body: After more than two weeks in which election results teetered from favoring one candidate to favoring another, the Board of Elections said yesterday that former State Senator Vincent Gentile was the winner of a special election for a City Council seat in Brooklyn. The results of the Feb. 25 special election hinged on absentee and other paper
title: After 2 Weeks, a Council Election Is Decided

body: The Board of Elections yesterday edged closer to a final count of ballots in the Feb. 25 special election for a City Council seat in Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, but some ballots may not be counted until later this week. The latest tally shows former State Senator Vincent Gentile with a lead of 16 votes over his closest rival, Rosemarie O'Keefe, who
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Election Results Still Not Final

author: Adam Davidson is the Middle East correspondent for the Minnesota Public Radio program ''Marketplace.''
body: Fadi is a 23-year-old unemployed computer programmer who lives in his parents' apartment in a nice, middle-class neighborhood in Amman, Jordan. Down one street is the big Amman McDonald's, down another is Fadi's mosque, where he prays several times a day. Stocky, with a big, messy beard, Fadi speaks softly, hunched over, looking at the ground. When
title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 3-9-03: ENCOUNTER; Loves Microsoft, Hates America

author: Richard B. Woodward is a writer and documentary maker in New York.
body: THE Vintage Weapons and Notorious Criminals Room at the New York City Police Museum near Hanover Square is a crowd-pleaser. Behind the plexiglass in a central case hang an array of captured revolvers, knives, clubs, hand grenades, the Thompson submachine gun used by a member of Al Capone's gang to bump off Frankie Yale and a collection of lock
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Small-Time Crooks

body: John Kennedy O'Hara, one of the few people ever prosecuted in New York for lying about his voting address, yesterday lost what may be the last round in a marathon legal battle against the Brooklyn district attorney. A federal judge, John Gleeson, rejected Mr. O'Hara's latest effort to contest a 1999 state court conviction that he has fought
title: Ex-Candidate Fails in Bid To Overturn Conviction

body: The Board of Election has not yet declared a winner of last week's special election for a City Council seat in Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, but they have come a bit closer. The board said yesterday that with all the ballots counted from the voting machines, Rosemarie O'Keefe, who was commissioner of the Community Assistance Unit under Mayor Rudolph
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Election Results Edge Closer

body: The intricate geography of income difference in New York City is something Chastity Davis absorbed early, growing up in the 1980's in a tenement apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on a block of mostly brick row houses flanked by public housing projects at either end. At the neighborhood elementary school, Ms. Davis's friends were from the
title: Here, Poverty And Privilege Are Neighbors; Income Gaps Are a Source Of Resentment and Guilt

body: Surrounded by Islamic incense shops and booksellers on Atlantic Avenue in the Boerum Hill neighborhood, imposing Al Farooq Mosque in Brooklyn has a history of raising money for Osama bin Laden, dating to the days when Mr. bin Laden and the United States had a common enemy in the Soviet occupiers of Afghanistan. Those days were supposed to be gone,
title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE MOSQUE; Brooklyn Muslims Disputing Any Ties to Terror

body: It will take a week or more to determine the winner in last Tuesday's special election for a City Council seat in Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, the New York City Board of Elections said yesterday. Officials said that unofficial results from the five-candidate race showed a virtual dead heat between former State Senator Vincent Gentile and Rosemarie
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: No Winner Yet In Council Races

body: Former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., a longtime Bronx official, was apparently returned to public office yesterday when he won a special election for a City Council seat. Mr. Espada will fill the remaining term of Ruben Diaz Sr., who defeated him in November in a Senate contest, another bruising battle. In a second hotly contested City Council
title: Espada Wins Council Race in the Bronx

body: Candidates in four special elections in Brooklyn and the Bronx worked feverishly into the night yesterday, with their staffs making phone calls, putting together car pool operations and placing final touches on efforts to draw voters to the polls today. Two of the special elections are for City Council seats, one in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx,
title: 2 Council and 2 Assembly Races Go to Voters Today

body: There will be four special elections today in New York City, two of them in Brooklyn and two in the Bronx. Polling places will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. In Brooklyn, voters in Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights and Bensonhurst will cast ballots in a nonpartisan City Council race. And in East New York and parts of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Brownsville,
title: Voting Hours for Special Elections

title: Brooklyn Council Candidates Find a Common Foe: the Property Tax Increase

Mr. Gentile, a Brooklyn Democrat who is running in a special election for a vacant seat, used a full-color photograph of the mayor's
title: Council Candidate Defends Using Photo of Mayor's House

The field of five candidates includes a wealth of longtime experience in the mostly working-class
title: Rosemarie O'Keefe for City Council

body: ''I got no eyes,'' said Daniel Tanner, 8, smiling. His mother, Grisel Ramos, rolled her own eyes. ''That's because you took your prosthetics out,'' she said. Daniel was born without the gift of sight. But he has other gifts: a quick tongue, easy charm and a singing voice that once inspired total strangers to offer him a karaoke machine. Daniel has
title: The Neediest Cases; Brothers and Family Get Help in Regaining Financial Footing

body: FRANK TROPEA stands on the Brooklyn Bridge, taking in the breathtaking view of Manhattan on a bitterly cold Saturday afternoon. Actually, he is standing about eight inches above the bridge, atop his Segway Human Transporter, the high-tech celebrity scooter. He has stopped because a young woman and her husband saw him riding along the bridge and ran
title: On the Pavement, A New Contender

body: A 63-year-old Bronx woman was killed yesterday in a hit-and-run accident that left her pinned against a wall of the Morris Heights Post Office, the police said. She was the fourth person to be killed in a rash of hit-and-run accidents in the city since Friday. The victim, Margarita Isaac, of 1972 Walton Avenue, was pronounced dead at the scene of
title: Driver Kills a Bronx Woman, 63, and Flees

body: A man tried to fire a loaded .45-caliber pistol at two people in a Brooklyn restaurant early yesterday, but the gun misfired and no one was hurt, according to the police. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Pistol Misfires Twice
